Boston.com
10
celtics 93, heat 91 (ot) | pictures

Celtics hold on in OT to win Game 4 and even East finals

Ray Allen defended the Heat's Dwyane Wade in the first quarter. Wade went for the win in overtime but his last-second three-pointer bounced off the rim. Elise Amendola/AP
Rajon Rondo dished the ball against the Heat's Shane Battier, left, during overtime of Game 4. Rondo finished with 15 points and a game-high 15 assists. Charles Krupa/AP
Rob Gronkowski of the New England Patriots celebrated during the game much to the delight of the fans, who cheered him and the Celtics on. Jim Rogash/Getty Images
Ray Allen checked his fingers after draining a three-pointer against the Miami Heat in the fourth quarter. Allen hit four treys and finished with 16 points. Elise Amendola/AP
Rajon Rondo acknowledged the crowd with a pointing gesture. Rondo powered Boston to a big lead before Miami stormed back late in regulation. Jim Rogash/Getty Images
In overtime, Mickael Pietrus of the Celtics drew NBA MVP LeBron James's sixth foul, eliminating James from playing in the remainder of overtime in Game 4. Charles Krupa/AP
Dwyane Wade reacted to missing a last-second three-pointer at the end of overtime in front of a jubilant Celtics bench. Wade had a game-high three steals. Al Diaz/AP
Ray Allen handed out celebratory high fives all around after the Celtics outlasted the Miami Heat in overtime. Game 5 is scheduled for Tuesday in Miami. Barry Chin/Globe Staff
Paul Pierce fired up his teammates in the huddle prior to Game 4 against the Miami Heat at TD Garden. Boston eked out a two-point overtime win. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images
A fan showed his colors during warmups, as the Celtics prepared for Game 4 of the Eastern Conference Finals against the Miami Heat Sunday. Barry Chin/Globe Staff
  • Celtics prevail in OT thriller and tie series | Box score
  • Ryan: Celtics didn’t make it easy in Game 4 win
  • No points, but Pietrus plays big | Allen puts game in gear
  • Video Highlights  |  Postgame reaction  |  Analysis
  • Heat got it half right on 'D' | Heat missed James at finish
  • On basketball Wade had his chance to win it at the end

Sen. Brown sought to loosen bank rules

Records show that after Scott Brown voted for the 2010 Wall Street overhaul, he worked to shield financial institutions from some of its tough provisions. (Globe)

E Ink looks beyond Kindle for next hit

E Ink Corp., the Cambridge firm that provides electronic displays for most of the world's e-readers, is shifting its focus to bicycle handlebars and traffic lights. (Globe)

High lead content ruins
city’s cherished compost

The thousands of tons of compost in the woods off American Legion Highway are now off-limits to Boston residents due to lead findings that puzzle scientists.
Opinion | Bob Ryan

Celtics didn’t make it easy in Game 4

After scoring 61 points in the first 24 minutes, the Celtics scored only 32 in the final 29, capping it off by winning in OT by a 4-2 score to even the series.

Mass. wind farm project takes shape

Ten developers are interested in building wind farms off the coast that together could generate nearly 10 times the amount of energy of the Cape Wind project.
Opinion | John E. Sununu

Private-sector propulsion

If a privately owned company can launch a rocket, why shouldn’t one handle the mail?

Helping children with sleep disorders

Nearly one-third of kids experience sleep issues at some point, but about 2 to 4 percent have structural defects that cause breathing difficulties during sleep.

New drugs stir hope on melanoma

After a decade of stalled progress, a flurry of new studies is sparking hope in the fight against the deadly skin cancer melanoma.

Painting a picture of performance

The new Massachusetts General Orthopaedics Sports Performance Center’s 3-D imaging is helping even injured amateur athletes regain their form.
